title: It's not too late to learn a new instrument
intro: Whether you grew up playing music or you never progressed beyond "Hot Cross Buns," it's not too late to pick up a new instrument. Let fun lead the way and lose yourself in the joy of learning. Joel Snape, who picked up piano at age 40, offers tips for beginners.

transcript.author: MARIELLE SEGARRA, BYLINE
transcript.text: You're listening to LIFE KIT...

transcript.author: SEGARRA
transcript.text: ...From NPR.

transcript.author: LILIANA MARIA PERCY RUIZ, HOST
transcript.text: Hey, everyone, I'm Liliana Maria Percy Ruiz in for Marielle Segarra. In 2019, Joel Snape moved back to his family home in England to take care of his dad, who had suddenly become seriously sick.

transcript.author: JOEL SNAPE
transcript.text: My dad was always kind of a - he would putter around with music. And he had this old Yamaha keyboard, and I was like - piano is kind of always something I've thought about trying. And so I thought, maybe this is a good time to try it. Like, maybe this is now or never. And it really gave me something to kind of focus on and put my energy into that felt a bit positive among, like, the other stuff that was happening.

transcript.author: PERCY RUIZ
transcript.text: Joel is a journalist, and he does lots of YouTube videos about the things he's learning about.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: OK, I've been learning piano for about 4 1/2 years now, and though people have been very nice about my progress, I think I could have probably learned more and improved faster if I knew then what I know now.

transcript.author: PERCY RUIZ
transcript.text: Joel was 40 years old when he started.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Basically very little experience playing music - like, I think I remembered, like, the old mnemonic, every good boy deserves favors, from, like, school. So that was as far as I had ever got with learning to read music.

transcript.author: PERCY RUIZ
transcript.text: So, yeah, he didn't really have a musical background, but he was drawn to music and the piano in particular.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: It sounds really strange, but actually, when "Westworld" came out, that had a big influence on my wanting to learn the piano, because they've got those beautiful piano arrangements of pop songs like Amy Winehouse.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: (Playing piano).

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I think I had seen the depth of the piano and all the things you could do with it.

transcript.author: PERCY RUIZ
transcript.text: Picking up an instrument as an adult can be intimidating. You're starting from scratch and playing dinky songs with three notes when some little kids can play Mozart. It can feel really embarrassing and the opposite of fun. In this episode of LIFE KIT, journalist Ruth Tam, who's picked up the ukulele recently, talks with Joel about learning an instrument as an adult. They'll discuss how to get motivated, strategies for practice and how to stick with it.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: (Playing piano).

transcript.author: RUTH TAM, BYLINE
transcript.text: I grew up playing piano and trumpet, and even though I really enjoyed it, I never felt like I could play without sheet music. Playing music felt like solving a math equation - challenging and fun, but ultimately extremely technical. But recently I picked up the ukulele, and that's required me to feel my way through a song. I'm learning to play more intuitively. And yeah, it's breaking my brain a little bit. But I can also feel myself rebuilding my relationship to music at the same time. I chose the ukulele because it just felt easy. It's small and portable, and I could get one for free. Shoutout to my sister, who's a music therapist and always has, like, two to three ukuleles at any given time.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: My advice, I think, would be to just start with whatever you have.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: I found Joel Snape on YouTube. We're learning different things. He taught himself piano. But he has plenty of advice for anyone learning a new instrument.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: If all you've got is, like, a keyboard that you found lying around your parents' house, or that you can find, you know, for cheap on Craigslist or wherever, then do that. And then upgrade, like, maybe as a gift to yourself when you know that you're really passionate about it and you want to make a go of it.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Joel tried learning guitar years ago because that's what he thought dudes like him should learn how to play. But he didn't like it. And it's only when he decided to sit down at the piano that he was genuinely excited to learn.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: One of the biggest things to overcome when you're picking an instrument is to not pick the kind of instrument that you think a person like you should be playing and go for the instrument that you actually want to play, you know? So I guess in your heart of hearts, what is it that you would actually like to be good at?

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Right now I've got a basic ukulele, and I'm going slow. I'm learning strum patterns and building finger strength, but I would like to graduate to the guitar at some point, and that's why I wanted to know what Joel's goal was when he first started learning the piano.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I think I had about two or three pieces that I really, really wanted to be able to play on piano. So one of them was "No Surprises" from "Westworld."

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: (Playing piano).

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: There's a cover version of a Pixies song called "Where Is My Mind?" by Max Cyrin.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: (Playing piano).

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I just thought it was beautiful. I think another thing that really shaped me wanting to learn was, in King's Cross St. Pancras, which is one of the big stations in London, they have two pianos just set up there for anybody to play. I think one of them was donated by Elton John. And I've always liked dropping by there to kind of hear what people are doing. And it was one of my goals when I first started out to get to a standard where I would feel comfortable, like, playing on one of those myself and hopefully not totally embarrassing myself.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: So Takeaway 1 - make this whole learning an instrument thing fun, and that starts with playing an instrument you actually want to play and practicing songs you actually enjoy. But sometimes you have to work up to that because when you're a beginner and you only know a few notes or some simple chords, you're stuck playing things like "Hot Cross Buns" or "When The Saints Go Marching In" really slowly. And that can feel really tedious and maybe even a little infantilizing too. So I asked Joel, how do you fight the part of not just feeling like a beginner, but feeling like a straight-up baby?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah, I mean, that's definitely a struggle. I think something that helped was that my learning was kind of self-directed, so I did jump in at the deep end and start trying to play stuff that was, like, probably too hard for me. So I was going through it, almost having to look up every note as I went along. So I was working on that, but I was kind of lucky that my wife plays the trumpet and knows a bit about music, so she kind of went, look, this is far too hard for you. I'm going to get you something easier. And she bought me a book called "Alfred's Piano Basic" (ph), which is the one that I now recommend to anybody who asks me, like, what my favorite resources are. And that's really basic stuff.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: And so I kind of split my playing time between the two of them. So I would spend, you know, maybe 10 minutes, 15 minutes a day doing scales and then later arpeggios and chords. And then I would maybe spend, like, 10, 15 minutes working on lessons from the book. And then if I'd done all that, I would kind of reward myself by spending, you know, 10 minutes and then 15 minutes on a couple of really hard pieces that I decided I was going to work on.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: So you, like, had your vegetables and then gave yourself dessert.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: That is a great way of putting it. Yeah. I would, like, get the good stuff in and then reward myself with where - you know, the stuff that was where I wanted to be eventually.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Takeaway two - practice with a plan. How did you develop a habit of practicing every day? First of all, did you practice every day?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah. In the early going, I practiced pretty much every day, and I practiced a lot. I mean, I think the most important thing about forming a habit is setting time aside when you're definitely going to practice. So maybe that's - you know, now for me, it's first thing in the morning, and then when - my wife and I kind of alternate who puts our 6-year-old to bed, so when it's her turn to put him to bed, I know I can get, like, a solid half-hour of practice in because that's how long his bedtime routine takes. So those are kind of times when it's almost nonnegotiable. That's just what I do at those times. That really helps.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: And then I guess the other thing about having a habit is, like, it helped that I always knew what I wanted to practice next. So in any given week I would be working on scales. You know, I might be working on C major, and I would always be doing that. So I could sit down at the piano and go, OK, today's C major. That's what I'm doing. So those are my two big tips for habit forming, I think. Have set times to do it, and know what you're going to do before you sit down at the piano.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: What would you say to the type of person who wants to learn music for fun about the importance of doing scales and technical drills? Like, why is it important to eat your vegetables musically?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Well, I mean, I think scales and technical stuff just make you more comfortable on the keyboard. It sounds like it's, like, boring and tedious, and I guess it can be if you're being forced to do it, you know, when you're a kid and you'd rather be doing other things. But just seeing the metronome tick up every day and feeling, like, your fluidity of your fingers go up can actually be a super satisfying experience. You know, it's kind of like leveling up in a video game, almost.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: That's a fun way of putting it. Speaking of leveling up in a video game, I feel like you made learning piano a serious priority, and I think it's hard to go from wanting to do something to actually committing to do it. Like, the unsexy fun of sitting down and playing and practicing and being bad at something consistently every day - like, you made it sound, like, kind of easy for you, like, that it was obvious that you would do these things and that it was a nonnegotiable. And I'm wondering, how did it actually feel at the time?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah. Hand independence, I think, was the thing that felt the hardest. And there were days when I was like, I'm not sure I'm going to be able to do this. Maybe, like, the neurons in my brain are too past it to wire together in this way. So it wasn't always easy, but I think it kind of helped that I do have experience of kind of learning stuff as an adult. So my other big hobby is Brazilian jiujitsu, which is kind of the polar opposite of piano in that it's something that you have to do with other people. You have to go to a gym and do it. But it's also just - it's a hard thing, like, and it's something I've done for a long time. So I think having done that, I kind of went into learning something else as an adult going, I think I'm capable of, like, learning to do things that are kind of difficult.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: I'm just speaking from my own experience here, where you're learning something new and you enter this stage where it's, like, not necessarily fun because it's novel, and there's this stage where you're in between being an absolute beginner and being, like, maybe an intermediate person, and you're kind of - maybe some people call it, like, your learning edge. You're, like, past the point of your comfort level. And it's just, like, very deeply unsettling to be so consistently bad at something. And I'm wondering, how do you navigate out of that stage?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah, I think I probably still do have moments like that where I'm like, have I really, you know, learnt as much as I should have, given the amount of time that I've been practicing, or - you know, and I think the hardest bit to get over was probably about six to nine months in where I was like, I've been practicing this, you know, a long time now. I've probably put in a couple of hundred hours, and there was stuff that I just still wasn't getting. And I think what kind of helped with that a little bit was just kind of almost taking a break from the stuff I was banging my head against and trying to do something else. So I think at the time, I was trying to do - there's a Mozart piece called "Sonata Facile" which means, like, I think, like, easy sonata or beginners sonata. And that's not easy at all. It's...

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I mean, it might have been easy for Mozart. And I was comparing myself against other people I'd seen learning online, as well.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: That's never a route you want to go...

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: No. There's...

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: ...Down, comparing yourself to other people on the internet.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: That's the last thing you want to do.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Takeaway three - find resources that work for you. Maybe that's a professional teacher or group lessons. For Joel, he found some really great, free, online resources, even though he does, ultimately, want a teacher.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I definitely think I should get a teacher. Yeah. It's one of my goals for this year. It's just a time issue, you know? It's - I know you can do online teaching, but I think I would rather sit down with somebody. And at the moment, I've got a job and a 6-year-old, and I've still got a Brazilian jiu-jitsu habit, so I've got lots to do.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: So in the absence of having access to a private teacher, I'm wondering if you have any creative, low-cost alternatives to that. I mean, you're a YouTube guy. I think there's, like, lots of resources on YouTube. Anything that you would recommend for others, either on YouTube or elsewhere?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah. So, I mean, I really recommend "Alfred's Piano Basics." So certainly the first book. I actually got into the second and third books, but I think once you've done the first one, that gives you a really good grounding to kind of move into the others. I think if anyone's on Reddit, the piano subreddit is kind of a super-helpful environment. They're really friendly to beginners, but they also have little challenges where they'll be like, oh, we're all going to try and learn this piece this month. Just, you know, record yourself playing it, put it up, you know, and nobody's going to criticize you. They'll give you feedback if you ask for it. But they're very supportive and they've got a lot of great resources, and that is a nice feeling, even though you're kind of an anonymous person talking to other anonymous people.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Nice. OK. Let's pull back a bit. Why is learning a new instrument worth all the time and effort?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: I think for me, learning a new instrument has kind of broadened my appreciation and understanding of music. So I can listen to, you know, classical pieces and stuff like Scott Joplin now and kind of appreciate it in a way I just didn't before. And I can sort of tell the difference between different composers. I think on a day-to-day basis, it's kind of one of the few things that I do in my life that doesn't involve staring at a screen. It's almost like a form of meditation. You know, when I go and sit down at the piano, I'm concentrating on that one thing, and it takes my mind away from work and everything else that I've got going on in my life, and it lets me just sort of breathe and relax. So it's great for me in that way. It's something you can make progress on in a little way every single day - well, pretty much every single day.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Depending on the day.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: There are days when I sit down and I'm like, yeah, that wasn't great. But, you know, if I've been banging my head against a difficult piece for a long time and I feel like I'm actually maybe getting worse at it, then that's - at some point, I'll, like, be sensible enough to just play something else for fun for a while, you know, like, pick something easier or just pick up a book and, like, sight read, you know, something a lot easier but that sounds nice and cool, and that kind of reminds me of what I'm doing it for.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: What would you play the next time you go to King's Crossing?

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Well, one that I am working on is Hans Zimmer's "He's A Pirate."

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: It's the theme tune from "Pirates Of The Caribbean," and it just sounds great.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Wait, the theme to the "Pirates Of The Caribbean" is just called "He's A Pirate?"

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yep.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: It's jaunty.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: It's very jaunty. It's a toe tapper.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Thanks, Joel. I'm going to leave my closet where I'm recording this interview and practice my ukulele now.

transcript.author: SNAPE
transcript.text: Amazing. Well, thank you very much for talking to me. Good luck with the ukulele.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Thanks.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: So here are some recaps from my time with Joel. Keep it fun. No one's making you do this. This is for your enjoyment, so keep that in mind with what instrument and songs you choose to play.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Practice with a plan. No one who ever said, oh, it might be nice to learn an instrument magically learned how to play that instrument. Determine when you have time to be mentally present and then fill that time with a specific practice plan. If you're Joel, that means eating your vegetables before dessert. So doing some technical drills followed by playing some fun songs.

transcript.author: TAM
transcript.text: Find resources that work for you. If you learn best with another person, or if you're looking for accountability, you might want to find a teacher to work with you. Or you can turn to online resources. There are a lot of free YouTube channels or subreddits for people learning new instruments.

transcript.author: PERCY RUIZ
